elements.content: Polymorphic transition from a metastable phase to a stable phase often occurs in metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) under the action of external stimuli. However, these transitions sometimes result in deteriorating their special performances and can even lead to serious safety problems. Therefore, developing a simple and efficient strategy for enhancing the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs is very imperative and meaningful. Herein, we propose a simple graphene oxide (GO)-encapsulating strategy for improving the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs. To illustrate this strategy, we designed and synthesized two polymorphic MOFs [MOF­(ATA-a) and MOF­(ATA-b)] as examples, which are based on energetic 5-amino-1H-tetrazole as ligands. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that these two polymorphs have a same chemical composition [Zn2(ATA)3(ATA)2/2] n , but different space groups, space systems, and different stacking modes of the neighboring ligands. As expected, the metastable polymorph [MOF­(ATA-a)] underwent a complete polymorphic transition at room temperature to form its stable polymorph [MOF­(ATA-b)]. Using the proposed strategy, we successfully encapsulated a small amount of GO in the metastable polymorph [GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a)]. The resultant composite exhibited better chemical stability, extremely higher thermal stability, and larger Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area compared to both its precursor and the physically mixed analogue. Remarkably, its onset decomposition temperature (T d) was as high as 377.4 °C, which is even higher than that of 1,3,5-triamino-2,4,6-trinitrobenzene (T d = 321 °C), making it a potential heat-resistant explosive. The mechanism of stabilization was investigated in detail using various analytical techniques. This work may not only provide new insights into the stabilization of functional MOF polymorphs but also open up a new field for the application of GO.

elements.content: Polymorphism, the phenomenon of a substance in two or more crystalline states, is of great scientific and commercial interest. Polymorphism arises from different conformations or packing arrangements in the crystal lattice. It is found in many classes of organic molecules such as triglycerides, saturated and unsaturated fatty acids, alkanes, aromatic π-bond systems, amino acids, and amides. Recently, this phenomenon has also been commonly found in crystalline coordination polymers, also known as metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), which are constructed exclusively through coordination bonds between organic ligands and metal ions; MOFs have exhibited potential applications in chemical separation, gas storage, sensors, drug delivery, catalysis, and energetic materials. Because of the flexible and diversified coordination modes, the combination of same ligands and metal ions can readily afford a variety of MOFs with distinct crystalline phases under different or even similar reaction conditions. For example, Zr–MOFs, a representative kind of MOFs, have more than four polymorphs with distinct pore structures, and they can be obtained from ZrCl4 and a tetrakis­(4-carboxyphenyl)­porphyrin ligand in a same reaction solvent dimethylformamide. Although different polymorphs of MOFs have chemical compositions similar to the case of organic molecules, they usually exhibit different properties such as stability, color, magnetism, luminescence, chirality, porosity, and heats of detonation; therefore, different polymorphs should be regarded, in fact, as different functional materials. External stimuli such as light, heat, and pressure usually induce polymorphic transitions from a metastable phase to a stable phase because of change in coordination number and geometry, dimensionality and interpenetration, and so forth. These transitions sometimes result in lowering their special performances and might even lead to serious safety problems. For instance, a three-dimensional (3D) porous MOF with a sodalite topology {[Ag­(dpzm)­(DMSO)]­ClO4} n (dpzm = di-2-pyrazinylmethane) has been demonstrated recently by Sumby to undergo porous 3D to nonporous two-dimensional (2D) polymorphic transition at room temperature, which results in greatly decreasing its surface area and thus lowering its absorption performances. In addition, energetic MOFs possess high densities and high heats of detonation and have exhibited promising applications in pyrotechnics, primary explosives, explosives, and energetic composites. Similar to traditional energetic molecules such as 1,3,5-trinitrohexahydro-s-triazine and hexanitrohexaazaisowurtzitane (CL-20), the polymorphic transitions of these MOFs can be even associated with deterioration or even disaster.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Polymorphism, the phenomenon of a substance in two or more crystalline states, is of great scientific and commercial interest. Polymorphism arises from different conformations or packing arrangements in the crystal lattice. It is found in many classes of organic molecules such as triglycerides, saturated and unsaturated fatty acids, alkanes, aromatic π-bond systems, amino acids, and amides. Recently, this phenomenon has also been commonly found in crystalline coordination polymers, also known as metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), which are constructed exclusively through coordination bonds between organic ligands and metal ions; MOFs have exhibited potential applications in chemical separation, gas storage, sensors, drug delivery, catalysis, and energetic materials. Because of the flexible and diversified coordination modes, the combination of same ligands and metal ions can readily afford a variety of MOFs with distinct crystalline phases under different or even similar reaction conditions. For example, Zr-MOFs, a representative kind of MOFs, have more than four polymorphs with distinct pore structures, and they can be obtained from ZrCl4 and a tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl)porphyrin ligand in a same reaction solvent dimethylformamide. Although different polymorphs of MOFs have chemical compositions similar to the case of organic molecules, they usually exhibit different properties such as stability, color, magnetism, luminescence, chirality, porosity, and heats of detonation; therefore, different polymorphs should be regarded, in fact, as different functional materials. External stimuli such as light, heat, and pressure usually induce polymorphic transitions from a metastable phase to a stable phase because of change in coordination number and geometry, dimensionality and interpenetration, and so forth. These transitions sometimes result in lowering their special performances and might even lead to serious safety problems. For instance, a three-dimensional (3D) porous MOF with a sodalite topology {[Ag(dpzm)(DMSO)]ClO4} n  (dpzm = di-2-pyrazinylmethane) has been demonstrated recently by Sumby to undergo porous 3D to nonporous two-dimensional (2D) polymorphic transition at room temperature, which results in greatly decreasing its surface area and thus lowering its absorption performances. In addition, energetic MOFs possess high densities and high heats of detonation and have exhibited promising applications in pyrotechnics, primary explosives, explosives, and energetic composites. Similar to traditional energetic molecules such as 1,3,5-trinitrohexahydro-s-triazine and hexanitrohexaazaisowurtzitane (CL-20), the polymorphic transitions of these MOFs can be even associated with deterioration or even disaster.

elements.content: Thus far, several methods have been invented to improve the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs such as using bulky hydrophobic organic ligands, introducing stable groups (−CF3) into organic ligands, incorporating mesocavities with microwindows, and forming strong coordination bonds (e.g., ZrIV–carboxylate bonds). However, these methods usually require tedious design and complicated synthetic steps, and sometime their scope of application is limited. Therefore, developing a simple and efficient method for improving the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs is very imperative.
elements.clean_text: Thus far, several methods have been invented to improve the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs such as using bulky hydrophobic organic ligands, introducing stable groups (-CF3) into organic ligands, incorporating mesocavities with microwindows, and forming strong coordination bonds (e.g., ZrIV-carboxylate bonds). However, these methods usually require tedious design and complicated synthetic steps, and sometime their scope of application is limited. Therefore, developing a simple and efficient method for improving the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs is very imperative.

elements.content: Graphene oxide (GO), a single layer of carbon atom in a closely packed honeycomb structure, is commercially available and has a very large surface area and low toxicity. It also possesses excellent thermal and mechanical properties. Moreover, it contains a large number of potentially coordinated oxygen functionalities such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, epoxy, and ketone. With these considerations in mind, we envisioned that encapsulating GO in MOFs might be an efficient strategy for enhancing the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs (). In the resulting hybrid composites, the oxygen functionalities of GO could coordinate with the metal ions of MOFs to form additional coordination bonds, thus enhancing the stabilities of MOFs. To date, research efforts have been mostly aimed to prepare new GO–MOF composites using nearly stoichiometric GO as templates or linkers and to study their applications in gas storage, chemical separation, and catalysis. In contrast, whether the GO-encapsulating strategy is applicable to enhance the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs has scarcely been demonstrated.
elements.clean_text: Graphene oxide (GO), a single layer of carbon atom in a closely packed honeycomb structure, is commercially available and has a very large surface area and low toxicity. It also possesses excellent thermal and mechanical properties. Moreover, it contains a large number of potentially coordinated oxygen functionalities such as hydroxyl, carboxyl, epoxy, and ketone. With these considerations in mind, we envisioned that encapsulating GO in MOFs might be an efficient strategy for enhancing the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs (). In the resulting hybrid composites, the oxygen functionalities of GO could coordinate with the metal ions of MOFs to form additional coordination bonds, thus enhancing the stabilities of MOFs. To date, research efforts have been mostly aimed to prepare new GO-MOF composites using nearly stoichiometric GO as templates or linkers and to study their applications in gas storage, chemical separation, and catalysis. In contrast, whether the GO-encapsulating strategy is applicable to enhance the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs has scarcely been demonstrated.

elements.content: To examine this possibility, we designed and synthesized two energetic MOFs [MOF­(ATA-a) and MOF­(ATA-b)] ( and S1) under similar reaction conditions as examples, in which 5-amino-1H-tetrazole (HATA) was chosen as the ligand because it contains a few of potentially coordinated nitrogen atoms; moreover, it has a high nitrogen content (82.3%) and heat of formation (208.7 kJ mol–1), which could contribute to the construction of high-energy MOFs. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that these two MOFs are polymorphic as they have a same chemical composition [Zn2(ATA)3(ATA)2/2] n , but different space groups, space systems, and different stacking modes of the neighboring ligands (, S3 and S4). As expected, the metastable polymorph [MOF­(ATA-a)] underwent a complete polymorphic transition ( and S5) at room temperature to form its stable polymorph counterpart [MOF­(ATA-b)]. To improve the stability of the metastable polymorph, we encapsulated a small amount of GO (≤1%) in MOF­(ATA-a), forming a hybrid composite [GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a)] ( and S2), in which the framework remained intact. The resultant composite exhibited better chemical stability, higher thermal stability, and larger Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area than both its precursor and the physically mixed analogue [GO/MOF­(ATA-a)]. Remarkably, its onset decomposition temperature (T d) was as high as 377.4 °C (Figures S6 and S7), which is even higher than that of 1,3,5-triamino-2,4,6-trinitrobenzene (TATB, T d = 321 °C), a well-known heat-resistant explosive. Meanwhile, the mechanism of stabilization was detailedly investigated through Raman spectroscopy, infrared spectrum (IR), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and atomic force microscope (AFM) techniques.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemicals and Materials

GO (1-5 layers) with an oxygen content over 42% was purchased from UIV Chem Yurui Chemical Corporation (Shanghai). Zinc nitrate hexahydrate (99%), zinc perchlorate hexahydrate (99%), and HATA (98%) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich Corporation.

elements.content: ZnNO3·6H2O (0.743 g, 2.5 mmol) and HATA (0.085 g, 1 mmol) were suspended in 10 mL of water and stirred at room temperature until the solution was clear and transparent. The mixture was transferred to a 20 mL hydrothermal reaction vessel and then heated at 160 °C for 48 h. After cooling down to room temperature, colorless and regular massive crystals were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 70% (based on HATA). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C2H5N10Zn (M = 233.5): C, 10.2; H, 2.1; and N, 60.0. Found: C, 9. 5; H, 2.4; and N, 58.7. IR (KBr pellets, λ, cm–1): 3198 (m), 1656 (s), 1573 (s), 1473 (s), 1326 (m), 1095 (s), 1010 (m), and 750 (m).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of MOF(ATA-a) and MOF(ATA-b)

MOF(ATA-a)

ZnNO3⋅6H2O (0.743 g, 2.5 mmol) and HATA (0.085 g, 1 mmol) were suspended in 10 mL of water and stirred at room temperature until the solution was clear and transparent. The mixture was transferred to a 20 mL hydrothermal reaction vessel and then heated at 160 °C for 48 h. After cooling down to room temperature, colorless and regular massive crystals were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 70% (based on HATA). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C2H5N10Zn (M = 233.5): C, 10.2; H, 2.1; and N, 60.0. Found: C, 9. 5; H, 2.4; and N, 58.7. IR (KBr pellets, λ, cm-1): 3198 (m), 1656 (s), 1573 (s), 1473 (s), 1326 (m), 1095 (s), 1010 (m), and 750 (m).

elements.content: The synthetic procedure was similar to that of MOF­(ata-a) except that ZnNO3·6H2O was replaced by Zn­(ClO4)2·6H2O. Colorless and irregular massive crystals were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 68% (based on HATA). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C2H5N10Zn (M = 233.5): C, 10.2; H, 2.1; and N, 60. Found: C, 9.6; H, 2.4; and N, 59.1. IR (KBr pellets, λ, cm–1): 3202 (m), 1656 (s), 1574 (s), 1474 (s), 1327 (m), 1094 (s), 1010 (m), and 750 (m).
elements.clean_text:
MOF(ata-b)

The synthetic procedure was similar to that of MOF(ata-a) except that ZnNO3⋅6H2O was replaced by Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O. Colorless and irregular massive crystals were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 68% (based on HATA). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C2H5N10Zn (M = 233.5): C, 10.2; H, 2.1; and N, 60. Found: C, 9.6; H, 2.4; and N, 59.1. IR (KBr pellets, λ, cm-1): 3202 (m), 1656 (s), 1574 (s), 1474 (s), 1327 (m), 1094 (s), 1010 (m), and 750 (m).

elements.content: Crystals of MOF­(ATA-a) were stored at room temperature under nitrogen atmospheres for 3 months, during which the crystals underwent a polymorphic transition, producing quantitatively new crystals [MOF­(ATA-b)]. The obtained crystals were still suitable for X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Moreover, when crystals of MOF­(ATA-a) were heated at 120 °C for 7.5 h or 160 °C for 4 h in an oven, the same transition was observed.
elements.clean_text:
Polymorphic Transition of MOF(ATA-a)

Crystals of MOF(ATA-a) were stored at room temperature under nitrogen atmospheres for 3 months, during which the crystals underwent a polymorphic transition, producing quantitatively new crystals [MOF(ATA-b)]. The obtained crystals were still suitable for X-ray single-crystal diffraction. Moreover, when crystals of MOF(ATA-a) were heated at 120 °C for 7.5 h or 160 °C for 4 h in an oven, the same transition was observed.

Black massive crystals were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 68% (based on HATA). IR (KBr pellets, λ, cm–1): 3200 (m), 1635 (s), 1568 (s), 1473 (s), 1326 (m), 1095 (s), 1010 (m), and 750 (m).

elements.content: To investigate the stability mechanism of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a), the GO–Zn complex was also prepared. Its synthetic procedure was similar to that of MOF­(ATA-a) except that the ligand ata was not added into the reaction mixture. Black powders were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the GO-Zn Complex

To investigate the stability mechanism of GO⊂MOF(ATA-a), the GO-Zn complex was also prepared. Its synthetic procedure was similar to that of MOF(ATA-a) except that the ligand ata was not added into the reaction mixture. Black powders were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air.

elements.content: According to the literature, MOF­(ATA-b) was prepared by the hydrothermal reaction of HATA with Zn­(ClO4)2·6H2O in water at 160 °C ( and S1). Interestingly, MOF­(ATA-a) in a similar synthetic manner similar to that for MOF­(ATA-b) except that Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O was used in place of Zn­(ClO4)2·6H2O, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) showed a new crystal [MOF­(ATA-a)] was obtained. These two materials can be synthesized with high yields and purities.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Crystal Structures of MOF(ATA-a) and MOF(ATA-b)

According to the literature, MOF(ATA-b) was prepared by the hydrothermal reaction of HATA with Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O in water at 160 °C ( and S1). Interestingly, MOF(ATA-a) in a similar synthetic manner similar to that for MOF(ATA-b) except that Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O was used in place of Zn(ClO4)2⋅6H2O, powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) showed a new crystal [MOF(ATA-a)] was obtained. These two materials can be synthesized with high yields and purities.

elements.content: To further confirm the structures of these two MOFs as well as to evaluate the differences between them, the crystals of these two materials were subjected to single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The results showed that these two materials exhibit very similar structures (, S3, and S4). They have the same formula {[Zn2(ATA)3(ATA)2/2] n } and asymmetry units. The unit is made up of two Zn2+ cations and five ATA– ligands, which contain three crystallographically independent ATA– groups and two crystallographically different halves of the ATA– ligands. Moreover, their ATA anions and Zn ions also display the same coordination modes, thus resulting in similar framework structures with same dimensions of channels (3 × 3 Å2). For example, each ATA anion serves as a μ2-bridge linking two Zn atoms, and each Zn atom is surrounded by four ATA– ligands. Parallel to [001], tetrahedrally coordinated Zn atoms are bridged by the μ2-ATA– ligands into 2D infinite layers. The 2D layers are interlinked by the same directional μ2-ATA– ligands to form a bilayer honeycomb feature. The 2D bilayers further pack along the [001] direction into a 3D hexagonal porous supramolecular structure via a π–π stacking interaction between neighboring ATA– ligands. Large and open hexagonal channels were generated along the [001] direction.

The 2D layers are interlinked by the same directional μ2-ATA- ligands to form a bilayer honeycomb feature. The 2D bilayers further pack along the [001] direction into a 3D hexagonal porous supramolecular structure via a π-π stacking interaction between neighboring ATA- ligands. Large and open hexagonal channels were generated along the [001] direction.

elements.content: However, there are a few remarkable differences between MOF­(ATA-a) and MOF­(ATA-b). These two materials have different space groups and space systems (, Table S1). MOF­(ATA-a) crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C12/m 1(12), whereas MOF­(ATA-b) crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Cm cm(63). The most significant difference between MOF­(ATA-a) and MOF­(ATA-b) is the stacking style of the neighboring ATA– ligands in the bilayer along the [001] direction. In MOF­(ATA-a), the neighboring ATA– ligands are reverse stacking, whereas they are homogeneous stacking in MOF­(ATA-b) (G,H). Meanwhile, the neighboring layers between the bilayers along the [001] direction are interlinked by ATA– ligands of different directional orientations. In MOF­(ATA-a), the neighboring layers are interlinked by the same direction ATA– ligands, whereas in MOF­(ATA-b), they are interlinked by the mirror plane symmetric ATA– ligands (I,J). Moreover, the distance between the neighboring layers decreased from 6.19 Å [MOF­(ATA-a)] to 6.17 Å [MOF­(ATA-b)], which indicated that there are denser π–π stacking interaction between the neighboring layers in MOF­(ATA-b) compared to MOF­(ATA-a). Therefore, single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that MOF­(ATA-a) and MOF­(ATA-b) are polymorphic.

elements.content: Polymorphic transitions are common in MOFs when subjected to external stimuli, such as heat. Surprisingly, when colorless crystals of MOF­(ATA-a) were stored even at room temperature under nitrogen atmospheres for 3 months, this polymorph underwent complete phase transition into a new polymorph [MOF­(ATA-b)], as demonstrated by PXRD (A). The peak corresponding to the (0, 1, 2) crystallographic plane at 26.85° (peak I) ascribed to MOF­(ATA-a) completely disappeared, and a new peak corresponding to the (1, 0, 0) plane at 27.10° (peak II) ascribed to MOF­(ATA-b) became particularly prominent. To further confirm the occurrence of this polymorphic transition, crystals of MOF­(ATA-a) were also heated at 120 °C for 7.5 h; the same transition could be clearly observed, and MOF­(ATA-b) was obtained (C). Moreover, when crystals of MOF­(ATA-a) were stored at room temperature for one month or heated at 120 °C for 2.5 h, an intermediate containing MOF­(ATA-a) and MOF­(ATA-b) could be obtained (A). However, the reverse transition did not occur even when MOF­(ATA-b) was heated at 160 °C for 48 h. Therefore, the results demonstrated that MOF­(ATA-a) is a metastable polymorph and can undergo a polymorphic transition to form MOF­(ATA-b). It is possible that denser π–π stacking interaction between the neighboring layers in MOF­(ATA-b) could contribute to improving its stability.

Polymorphic Transition between MOF(ATA-a) and MOF(ATA-b)

Polymorphic transitions are common in MOFs when subjected to external stimuli, such as heat. Surprisingly, when colorless crystals of MOF(ATA-a) were stored even at room temperature under nitrogen atmospheres for 3 months, this polymorph underwent complete phase transition into a new polymorph [MOF(ATA-b)], as demonstrated by PXRD (A). The peak corresponding to the (0, 1, 2) crystallographic plane at 26.85° (peak I) ascribed to MOF(ATA-a) completely disappeared, and a new peak corresponding to the (1, 0, 0) plane at 27.10° (peak II) ascribed to MOF(ATA-b) became particularly prominent. To further confirm the occurrence of this polymorphic transition, crystals of MOF(ATA-a) were also heated at 120 °C for 7.5 h; the same transition could be clearly observed, and MOF(ATA-b) was obtained (C). Moreover, when crystals of MOF(ATA-a) were stored at room temperature for one month or heated at 120 °C for 2.5 h, an intermediate containing MOF(ATA-a) and MOF(ATA-b) could be obtained (A). However, the reverse transition did not occur even when MOF(ATA-b) was heated at 160 °C for 48 h. Therefore, the results demonstrated that MOF(ATA-a) is a metastable polymorph and can undergo a polymorphic transition to form MOF(ATA-b). It is possible that denser π-π stacking interaction between the neighboring layers in MOF(ATA-b) could contribute to improving its stability.

elements.content: To improve the stability of the metastable polymorph, we encapsulated GO in MOF­(ATA-a) to form a hybrid composite [GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a)] (). The synthesis of the composite is very simple; it is similar to that of MOF­(ATA-a) except that tiny amounts of GO (1%) were also added in the precursor solution. The resultant composite was black (Figure S2), whereas its precursor was colorless (Figure S1), which indicates that GO was successfully encapsulated in the composite. Moreover, its PXRD pattern () was identical to that of its precursor [MOF­(ATA-a)], suggesting that the framework remained intact after encapsulation.
elements.clean_text:
Stabilizing MOF(ATA-a) vis the Proposed Strategy

To improve the stability of the metastable polymorph, we encapsulated GO in MOF(ATA-a) to form a hybrid composite [GO⊂MOF(ATA-a)] (). The synthesis of the composite is very simple; it is similar to that of MOF(ATA-a) except that tiny amounts of GO (1%) were also added in the precursor solution. The resultant composite was black (Figure S2), whereas its precursor was colorless (Figure S1), which indicates that GO was successfully encapsulated in the composite. Moreover, its PXRD pattern () was identical to that of its precursor [MOF(ATA-a)], suggesting that the framework remained intact after encapsulation.

elements.content: To further confirm the existence of GO in GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) as well as to analyze the texture of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a), a series of SEM images of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a), MOF­(ATA-a), GO, and the physically mixed composite GO/MOF­(ATA-a) as the reference material ( and S8) were obtained. In GO (A), it was observed that the stacked GO sheets with a smooth and flat morphology can be well separated. In the case of MOF­(ATA-a) and GO/MOF­(ATA-a), a well-defined massive crystal was observed with some remains of an amorphous phase (B,C). However, unlike MOF­(ATA-a) and GO/MOF­(ATA-a), GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) exhibits a smooth surface (D), probably because GO with a stable single layer of carbon atoms was combined with MOF­(ATA-a). Additionally, energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental maps of GO (E) show that the material contains large quantities of elemental O, which can be attributed to the presence of oxygen-containing functional groups under the surfaces of its layers. The EDS elemental maps of MOF­(ATA-a) (F), on the other hand, show that it contains only small amounts of elemental O, which was confirmed from its single-crystal structure and elemental analysis. Nevertheless, G,H shows that GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) and GO/MOF­(ATA-a) contain large quantities of elemental O, which can only come from GO, thus further confirming that GO was successfully encapsulated in GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a). Moreover, compared to GO/MOF­(ATA-a), GO was more evenly distributed in GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a).

elements.content: Next, the stability of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) was examined by PXRD and IR analysis. Gratifyingly, GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) was found to be quite stable in common solvents and remained stable in air for 3 months (). To investigate the chemical stabilities of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) and its precursor, we dispersed these as-prepared samples in aqueous solutions with different pH values (1 and 14) for 12 h. After that, the samples were thoroughly washed with water and dried before characterization. As shown in E, the PXRD patterns of these materials were almost completely similar in the pH 1 aqueous solution. However, when the pH of the solution was 14, the diffraction peaks of MOF­(ATA-a) completely disappeared (E, peak III and IV) and some new peaks appeared (E, peak V), whereas those of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) remained intact (Figures S9 and S10). Interestingly, MOF­(ATA-a) was completely dissolved after soaking in pH 1 aqueous solution for 18 h. In contrast, GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) remained unchanged for 18 h (, S10). The above results showed that GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) exhibits high chemical stabilities in both acid and base solutions, allowing their applications under different conditions.

elements.content: In addition to its high chemical stability, the composite also exhibited an extremely high thermal stability. The PXRD patterns (B) and IR analysis (Figure S10) indicated that the composite was intact even after heating it at 120 °C for 24 h. However, the stability of MOF­(ATA-a) did not obviously improve even when physically mixed with GO [GO/MOF­(ATA-a), D]. Thermogravimetric/differential scanning calorimetry analysis unambiguously demonstrated that the onset decomposition temperature of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) was 377.4 °C (Figure S7), which is even higher than that of TATB (321 °C), and hence, it can be used as a potential heat-resistant explosive. Therefore, the above-described results confirmed that the proposed GO-encapsulating strategy is a simple and efficient method for enhancing the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs.

elements.clean_text:
Investigation on the Stability Mechanism of the Proposed Strategy

To disclose the stabilizing mechanism of this strategy, the chemical bonds, structures, and morphologies of GO⊂MOF(ATA-a) were determined by Raman spectroscopy, IR, XPS, SEM, TEM, and AFM; GO, MOF(ATA-a), GO/MOF(ATA-a), and the GO-Zn complex were also analyzed as the reference materials.

elements.content: Raman spectroscopy was first used to investigate the interactions between GO and MOF­(ATA-a) ( and S11). According to the literature, in the Raman spectrum of GO, the defect of its hybridized band carbon atoms and first-order band carbon atoms equals the enhanced D band intensity. When isolated double bonds are present, the G band becomes much broader (A). However, in the Raman spectrum of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) (D), these two peaks are difficult to spot possibly because of the low content of GO in GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a), which is similar to that of GO/MOF­(ATA-a). In addition, there are some obvious characteristic peaks of MOF­(ATA-a) in the spectrum of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) including the peaks at 770 cm–1 (tetrazole ring vibration), 1011 cm–1 (tetrazole ring vibration), 1110 cm–1 (N–N/tetrazole ring vibration), 1327 cm–1 (tetrazole ring vibration), 1565 cm–1 (N−), 3204 cm–1 (NH2), and 3338 cm–1(NH2), which are further confirmed by its IR analyses. However, the characteristic peak at 491 cm–1 ascribed to the framework has an apparent change compared to that of its precursor [MOF­(ATA-a), 484 cm–1], probably because of the interactions between GO and MOF­(ATA-a).

elements.content: To further demonstrate the interactions between GO and MOF­(ATA-a) in GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a), XPS technique was also carried out ( and S13). In the XPS spectrum of GO, the fitted C 1s peaks at 288.9 eV (HO–CO), 287.9 eV (CO), and 287.9 eV (C–O/C–O–C) are clearly observed according to XPS peak fitting principles (E), confirming that GO possesses abundant functional groups. In the XPS spectrum of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) (H), a new C 1s peak at 288.9 eV (HO–CO/ZnO–CO) was appeared when compared with those of MOF­(ATA-a) (F), which is attributed to Zn–O coordination bonds between GO and MOF­(ATA-a). This observation strongly supports our initial postulation that GO with a large number of oxygen functionalities could easily be coordinated with the metal ions of MOFs. To further confirm that GO can coordinate with Zn ions, the GO–Zn complex was also synthesized using a process similar to that followed for the synthesis of MOF­(ATA-a), except that the ligand HATA was not added to the reaction solution. In the XPS spectrum of the as-prepared GO–Zn complex, a fitted Zn 2P3/2 (Zn–O) peak (L) at 1421.47 eV was apparent, which confirms that a coordination reaction can occur between Zn­(II) ions and the functional groups of GO. Meanwhile, GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) also shows the same peaks in the Zn 2p3/2 curves at 1421.47 eV, which can be attributed to the presence of a Zn–O bond in this composite. Moreover, the fitted N 1s peaks of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) showed the existence of a novel contribution at a binding energy 400.9 eV­(N+) as compared to those of MOF­(ATA-a) and GO; this new peak can be assigned to positively charged nitrogen atoms, as a result of coordination interactions between the MOF­(ATA-a) and GO. Similarly, these XPS peaks can also observed in the XPS spectrum of GO/MOF­(ATA-a) (G).

elements.content: To highlight the significance of GO encapsulation compared to physically mixed GO as well as to disclose why GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) possesses an extremely high stability when compared to the physically mixed composite GO/MOF­(ATA-a), TEM was conducted to observe the difference in the interface structure of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) and GO/MOF­(ATA-a). In terms of the morphology of GO, the TEM images () showed some obvious differences between GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) and GO/MOF­(ATA-a). In GO/MOF­(ATA-a) (C), there were a large number of unfolded GO layers wrapped with the MOF­(ATA-a) particles. However, GO in GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) (D) was much more wrinkled than that of GO/MOF­(ATA-a). The difference in the morphologies of GO could be attributed to the different modes of interaction between GO and MOF­(ATA-a). In GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a), GO was evenly distributed and its oxygen functionalities can interact with a large number of Zn ions in MOF­(ATA-a) to form extensive coordination bonds, resulting in strong coordination interactions (L). Hence, these strong coordination interactions led to the wrinkled morphology of GO when it was deposited on MOF­(ATA-a) (D). In contrast, in GO/MOF­(ATA-a) (C), most of the GO is aggregated and thus only a few GO can interact with Zn ions of MOF­(ATA-a), thus forming very few coordination bonds; as a result, the morphology of GO remains unchanged. Therefore, the high stability of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) results from strong coordination interactions between GO and MOF­(ATA-a), whereas the scenario in GO/MOF­(ATA-a) is just the opposite. Furthermore, only the encapsulation of GO in MOFs can improve the stabilities of metastable MOF polymorphs, whereas physically mixing GO into MOFs cannot do that.

elements.content: We also used AFM to determine the more microscopic and concrete morphologies of the GO in GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) hybrid composites. In the AFM image of GO (A), the smooth, flat, and stacked GO sheets were observed; they were approximately 3–5 nm and are well separated (C). In the case of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a), the sheet structure of GO was retained; the height change diagram of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) further showed that the GO sheet possesses a smooth, flat, and pucker-free surface without any distortions (C). It is possible that GO and MOF­(ATA-a) both have abundant π-conjugation systems and layered structures, which could produce a dense layer-by-layer stacking between them, thus allowing GO to retain its sheet structure.

In the case of GO⊂MOF(ATA-a), the sheet structure of GO was retained; the height change diagram of GO⊂MOF(ATA-a) further showed that the GO sheet possesses a smooth, flat, and pucker-free surface without any distortions (C). It is possible that GO and MOF(ATA-a) both have abundant π-conjugation systems and layered structures, which could produce a dense layer-by-layer stacking between them, thus allowing GO to retain its sheet structure.

elements.content: Thus, according to the above results, the stabilizing mechanism of this strategy is as follows: GO contains a number of potentially coordinated oxygen functionalities; meanwhile, GO is evenly distributed in the composite, which results in the formation of extensive and additional coordination bonds between GO and the metastable MOF polymorphs, which improves its stabilities. However, in physically mixed composites, there are only a few coordination bonds between GO and the metastable MOF polymorphs, which makes it difficult to improve the stability of the metastable polymorphs.

However, in physically mixed composites, there are only a few coordination bonds between GO and the metastable MOF polymorphs, which makes it difficult to improve the stability of the metastable polymorphs.

elements.content: Energetic MOFs have exhibited promising applications in pyrotechnics, primary explosives, explosives, and energetic composites because of their high densities and high heats of detonation. Besides the thermal stability, another energetic properties of pristine MOF­(ATA-a), GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a), and GO/MOF­(ATA-a) such as density, sensitivity, and heat of detonation were also evaluated because these materials contain energetic ATA ligands and energetic 2D frameworks. Remarkably, these materials exhibited extremely low sensitivities toward impact, friction, and static electricity. According to the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, these materials are insensitive [impact sensitivity (IS) > 40 J; friction sensitivity (FS) > 360 N; electrostatic sensitivity (ESD) > 24.75] (see the Supporting Information). Automatic density analyses show that these three materials have the same density (1.62 g cm–3) possibly because of the low content of GO in these composites. According to our developed method, the heats of detonation of these energetic materials were also calculated using the experimentally determined [back-calculated from volume energy of combustion] enthalpies of formation and the experimentally measured densities (See the Supporting Information). The calculated heats of detonation for GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) and GO/MOF­(ATA-a) were 1906.5 and 1891.5 J g–1, respectively, which are slightly superior to those of the precursor [MOF­(ATA-a), 1858.2 J g–1]. On the basis of its extremely high thermal stability, low sensitivity, and acceptable heat of detonation, GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) could be used as a potential heat-resistant explosive.
elements.clean_text:
Properties of MOF(ATA-a) and its Composites

Energetic MOFs have exhibited promising applications in pyrotechnics, primary explosives, explosives, and energetic composites because of their high densities and high heats of detonation. Besides the thermal stability, another energetic properties of pristine MOF(ATA-a), GO⊂MOF(ATA-a), and GO/MOF(ATA-a) such as density, sensitivity, and heat of detonation were also evaluated because these materials contain energetic ATA ligands and energetic 2D frameworks. Remarkably, these materials exhibited extremely low sensitivities toward impact, friction, and static electricity. According to the UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods, these materials are insensitive [impact sensitivity (IS) > 40 J; friction sensitivity (FS) > 360 N; electrostatic sensitivity (ESD) > 24.75] (see the Supporting Information). Automatic density analyses show that these three materials have the same density (1.62 g cm-3) possibly because of the low content of GO in these composites. According to our developed method, the heats of detonation of these energetic materials were also calculated using the experimentally determined [back-calculated from volume energy of combustion] enthalpies of formation and the experimentally measured densities (See the Supporting Information). The calculated heats of detonation for GO⊂MOF(ATA-a) and GO/MOF(ATA-a) were 1906.5 and 1891.5 J g-1, respectively, which are slightly superior to those of the precursor [MOF(ATA-a), 1858.2 J g-1]. On the basis of its extremely high thermal stability, low sensitivity, and acceptable heat of detonation, GO⊂MOF(ATA-a) could be used as a potential heat-resistant explosive.

elements.content: Interestingly, GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) exhibits a slightly higher BET surface area than MOF­(ATA-a) and GO/MOF­(ATA-a) [GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a), 324.5 m2 g–1; MOF­(ATA-a), 303.2 m2 g–1; GO/MOF­(ATA-a), 305.3 m2 g–1] (). It is possible that the encapsulated GO is evenly distributed, which could extend the limited backbone, thus enhancing the surface area. Therefore, we envisioned that encapsulating GO in MOF polymorphs can also be an efficient strategy for enhancing their surface area, which is one of the most important requirements for their application in gas absorption and storage, chemical separation, and drug delivery.

elements.content: In summary, we have proposed a simple strategy for encapsulating GO in metastable MOF polymorphs to improve their stabilities. To validate our hypothesis, two polymorphic ATA-based MOFs [MOF­(ATA-a) and MOF­(ATA-b)] as examples were synthesized under similar reaction conditions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that these two MOFs have the same chemical composition but different space groups and space systems and different stacking modes of the neighboring ligands. The metastable polymorph [MOF­(ATA-a)] underwent a complete polymorphic transition at room temperature to form its stable polymorph [MOF­(ATA-b)]. By applying this strategy, we encapsulated GO in a metastable MOF polymorphic to form a hybrid composite [GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a)]. Its SEM showed that GO was evenly distributed in the composite. As a result, this composite exhibited better chemical stability in both acid and base solutions, extremely higher thermal stability, and a larger BET surface area than both its precursor and physically mixed composite; furthermore, it has acceptable heat of detonation and extremely low sensitivity. Remarkably, the onset decomposition temperature of GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) was as high as 377.4 °C, which is even higher than that of TATB (318 °C). Therefore, GO⊂MOF­(ATA-a) could be a potential heat-resistant explosive. Experimental mechanistic studies clearly revealed that extensive coordination bonds between GO and metastable MOF polymorphs in this hybrid composite can result in enhancing their stabilities. This work may not only provide new insights into the stabilization of functional MOF polymorphs but also open up a new field for the application of GO.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have proposed a simple strategy for encapsulating GO in metastable MOF polymorphs to improve their stabilities. To validate our hypothesis, two polymorphic ATA-based MOFs [MOF(ATA-a) and MOF(ATA-b)] as examples were synthesized under similar reaction conditions. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction showed that these two MOFs have the same chemical composition but different space groups and space systems and different stacking modes of the neighboring ligands. The metastable polymorph [MOF(ATA-a)] underwent a complete polymorphic transition at room temperature to form its stable polymorph [MOF(ATA-b)]. By applying this strategy, we encapsulated GO in a metastable MOF polymorphic to form a hybrid composite [GO⊂MOF(ATA-a)]. Its SEM showed that GO was evenly distributed in the composite. As a result, this composite exhibited better chemical stability in both acid and base solutions, extremely higher thermal stability, and a larger BET surface area than both its precursor and physically mixed composite; furthermore, it has acceptable heat of detonation and extremely low sensitivity. Remarkably, the onset decomposition temperature of GO⊂MOF(ATA-a) was as high as 377.4 °C, which is even higher than that of TATB (318 °C). Therefore, GO⊂MOF(ATA-a) could be a potential heat-resistant explosive. Experimental mechanistic studies clearly revealed that extensive coordination bonds between GO and metastable MOF polymorphs in this hybrid composite can result in enhancing their stabilities. This work may not only provide new insights into the stabilization of functional MOF polymorphs but also open up a new field for the application of GO.

cln_elements.content:
ZnNO3·6H2O (0.743 g, 2.5 mmol) and HATA (0.085 g, 1 mmol) were suspended in 10 mL of water and stirred at room temperature until the solution was clear and transparent. The mixture was transferred to a 20 mL hydrothermal reaction vessel and then heated at 160 °C for 48 h. After cooling down to room temperature, colorless and regular massive crystals were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 70% (based on HATA). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C2H5N10Zn (M = 233.5): C, 10.2; H, 2.1; and N, 60.0. Found: C, 9. 5; H, 2.4; and N, 58.7. IR (KBr pellets, λ, cm–1): 3198 (m), 1656 (s), 1573 (s), 1473 (s), 1326 (m), 1095 (s), 1010 (m), and 750 (m).

MOF­(ata-b)

The synthetic procedure was similar to that of MOF­(ata-a) except that ZnNO3·6H2O was replaced by Zn­(ClO4)2·6H2O. Colorless and irregular massive crystals were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 68% (based on HATA). Elemental analysis (%) calculated for C2H5N10Zn (M = 233.5): C, 10.2; H, 2.1; and N, 60. Found: C, 9.6; H, 2.4; and N, 59.1. IR (KBr pellets, λ, cm–1): 3202 (m), 1656 (s), 1574 (s), 1474 (s), 1327 (m), 1094 (s), 1010 (m), and 750 (m).

GO⊂MOF­(ATA-b)

The synthetic procedure was similar to that of MOF­(ATA-b) except that GO powder was also added into the solution during stirring at room temperature. Black massive crystals were obtained after filtration, washed with water, and dried in air. Yield: 68% (based on HATA). IR (KBr pellets, λ, cm–1): 3201 (m), 1635 (s), 1568 (s), 1473 (s), 1326 (m), 1095 (s), 1010 (m), and 750 (m).
